column1: The Independence Movement in Puerto Rico refers to initiatives by inhabitants throughout the history of Puerto Rico to obtain full political independence for the island
column2: first from the Spanish Empire
column3: from 1493 to 1898 and
column4: since 1898
column5: from the United States. A variety of groups
column6: movements
column7: political parties
column8: and organizations have struggled for Puerto Rico's independence over the centuries.

column2: pro-nationalism
column3: and pro-independence sentiments and political parties exist on the island. Since the beginning of the 19th century
column4: organizations advocating independence in Puerto Rico have attempted both peaceful political means as well as violent revolutionary actions to achieve its objectives.

column1: Since the second half of the 20th century
column2: the independence movement has not been widely supported by the Puerto Rican public
column3: failing to gain traction in both plebiscites and elections. In a status referendum in 2012
column4: 5.5% voted for independence while Statehood obtained 61.1% of the votes cast. Independence also received the least support
column5: less than 4.5% of the vote
column6: in the status referendums in 1967

column1: A fourth referendum was held in 2012
column2: with 54% voting to change Puerto Rico's status but the federal government took no action to do so. The fifth plebiscite was held on June 11
column3: 2017. With a voter turnout of 23%
column4: it had the lowest turnout of any status referendum held in Puerto Rico.  The independence option only received 1.5% of the vote in the referendum.

column1: Some Modern Puerto Rican independence movements have claimed historic connection to the 16th century and the Taíno rebellion of 1511 led by Agüeybaná II. In this revolt
column2: Agüeybaná II
column3: the most powerful cacique at the time
column4: together with Urayoán
column5: cacique of Añasco
column6: organized a revolt in 1511 against the Spaniards in the southern and western parts of the island. He was joined by Guarionex
column7: cacique of Utuado
column8: who attacked the village of Sotomayor (present-day Aguada) and killed 80 Spanish colonists. Juan Ponce de León led the Spaniards in a series of offensives that culminated in the Battle of Yagüecas. Agüeybaná II's people
column9: who were armed only with spears
column12: were no match for the guns of the Spanish forces
column13: and Agüeybaná II was shot and killed in the battle. The revolt ultimately failed
column14: and many Taíno either committed suicide or fled the island.

column1: Several revolts against the Spanish rulers by the native born
column2: or Criollos
column3: occurred in the 19th century.  These include the conspiracy at San Germán in 1809
column4: and the uprisings of people in Ciales
column5: San Germán and Sabana Grande in 1898.Many Puerto Ricans became inspired by the ideals of Simón Bolívar to liberate South America from Spanish rule. Bolívar sought to create a federation of Latin American nations
column6: to include Puerto Rico and Cuba. Brigadier General Antonio Valero de Bernabé
column7: also known as "The Liberator from Puerto Rico"
column8: fought for the independence of South America together with Bolívar; he also wanted an independent Puerto Rico.

column2: the first female Puerto Rican Independentista
column3: joined forces with the Venezuelan government
column4: under the leadership of Simón Bolívar
column5: to lead an insurrection against the Spanish colonial forces in Puerto Rico. The Spanish occupation forces were the object of more than thirty conspiracies. Some
column6: like the Lares uprising
column7: the riots and sedition of 1897 and the Secret Societies at the end of the 19th century
column8: became popular rebellions. The most widespread popular revolts
column10: were the one in Lares in 1868
column11: and the one in Yauco in 1897.

column2: the Grito de Lares took place
column3: in which revolutionaries occupied the town of Lares and declared the Republic of Puerto Rico. Ramón Emeterio Betances was the leader of this revolt. Earlier
column4: Segundo Ruiz Belvis and Betances had founded the Comité Revolucionario de Puerto Rico (Revolutionary Committee of Puerto Rico) from their exile in the Dominican Republic. Betances wrote several Proclamas
column5: or statements attacking the exploitation of the Puerto Ricans by the Spanish colonial system
column6: and called for immediate insurrection. These statements were rapidly circulated throughout the island as local dissident groups began to organize.

column1: Most dissidents were Criollos (born on the island). The critical state of the economy
column2: along with the increasing repression imposed by the Spanish
column3: served as catalysts for the rebellion. The stronghold of the movement were towns located on the mountains of the west of the island.  The rebels looted local stores and offices owned by peninsulares (Spanish-born residents) and took over the city hall. They took as prisoners Spanish merchants and local government officials. The revolutionaries placed their revolutionary flag (the first Puerto Rican flag) on the high altar of the church to signify that the revolution had begun. The Republic of Puerto Rico was proclaimed
column4: and Francisco Ramírez Medina was proclaimed interim president. The revolutionaries offered immediate freedom to any slave who would join them.

column2: San Sebastián del Pepino
column3: the Grito de Lares revolutionaries encountered heavy resistance from the Spanish militia and retreated to Lares.  The Spanish militia rounded up the rebels and quickly brought the insurrection to an end.  The government imprisoned some 475 rebels
column4: and a military court imposed the death penalty
column5: for treason and sedition
column6: on all the prisoners.  But in Madrid
column7: Eugenio María de Hostos and other prominent Puerto Ricans were successful in interceding
column8: and the national government ordered a general amnesty and release of all the prisoners. Numerous leaders

column2: a group of residents of Yauco who supported independence joined forces to overthrow the Spanish government in the island. The group was led by Antonio Mattei Lluberas
column3: a wealthy coffee plantation owner
column4: and Mateo Mercado. Later that year
column5: the local Civil Guard discovered their plans and arrested all those involved. They were soon released and allowed to return home.In 1897
column6: Lluberas traveled to New York City and visited the Puerto Rican Revolutionary Committee
column7: which included the exiled group from the 1868 Grito de Lares revolt. They made plans for a major coup in Puerto Rico. Lluberas returned to Puerto Rico with a Puerto Rican flag to be flown at such coup. The Mayor of Yauco
column8: Francisco Lluch Barreras
column10: and notified the island's Spanish governor. When Fidel Velez
column12: learned that the word was out
column13: he met with other leaders and forced them to begin the insurrection immediately.On March 24
column15: Velez and his men marched towards Yauco
column16: planning to attack the barracks of the Spanish Civil Guard
column17: to gain control of their arms and ammunition. At arrival
column18: they were ambushed by Spanish forces. When a firefight broke out

column2: a group headed by Jose Nicolas Quiñones Torres and Ramon Torres fought Spanish colonial forces (mostly island men) in a barrio called Quebradas of Yauco
column3: but were overcome. The government arrested more than 150 rebels
column4: charged them with various crimes against the state
column5: and sent them to prison in the City of Ponce. These attacks became known as the Intentona de Yauco (Attempted Coup of Yauco). It was the first time that the flag of Puerto Rico was flown on the island.Velez fled to St. Thomas where he lived in exile. Mattei Lluberas went into exile in New York City
column6: joining a group known as the "Puerto Rican Commission".

column1: After four hundred years of colonial rule by the Spanish Empire
column2: Puerto Rico finally received its sovereignty in 1897 through a Carta de Autonomía (Charter of Autonomy). It was signed by Spanish Prime Minister Práxedes Mateo Sagasta and ratified by the Spanish Cortes.

column1: == Seeking independence from the United States ==

column2: the United States claimed ownership of the island as part of the Treaty of Paris of 1898
column3: which concluded the Spanish–American War
column4: which they had won that year. On 19 February 1904
column5: the Union of Puerto Rico party became the first mass party to advocate for independence for Puerto Rico in the form of a sovereign nation. Other "independence parties" were formed in reaction to the colonial status of Puerto Rico with the United States. The Puerto Rican Nationalist Party
column6: founded 17 September 1922
column7: also advocates independence. This party has since held that
column8: by international law
column9: the Spanish had no authority under the Treaty of Paris to cede the island
column10: which was no longer theirs. The Nationalist movement attracted supporters following the repressions by the island government in the Ponce and the Río Piedras massacre. The profits generated by this one-sided arrangement were enormous
column11: as US corporations developed large plantations.Several years after leaving office
column13: the first civilian U.S. governor of Puerto Rico
column14: succeeded to the presidency of the American Sugar Refining Company after serving as treasurer. He resigned in 1915
column15: but stayed on the board. The company operated the largest sugar-refining operation in the world and was later renamed as the Domino Sugar company. According to historian Federico Ribes Tovar
column16: Charles Allen leveraged his governorship of Puerto Rico into a controlling interest over the entire Puerto Rican economy through Domino Sugar.American professor and activist Noam Chomsky argued in the late 20th century that
column17: after 1898 "Puerto Rico was turned into a plantation for U.S. agribusiness
column18: later an export platform for taxpayer-subsidized U.S. corporations
column19: and the site of major U.S. military bases and petroleum refineries." By 1930
column20: over 40 percent of all the arable land in Puerto Rico had been converted into sugar plantations owned by Domino Sugar and U.S. banking interests. These bank syndicates also owned the insular postal system
column22: and the San Juan international seaport.Taking Puerto Rico was seen as a part of American "Manifest destiny." The American government supported American corporations with military force on occasion.

column1: After Puerto Rico was invaded during the Spanish–American War in 1898
column2: Manuel Zeno Gandía traveled to Washington
column3: D.C. where
column4: together with Eugenio María de Hostos
column5: he proposed the idea of independence for Puerto Rico.  The men were disappointed when their ideas were rejected by the US government and the island was organized as a US territory.  Zeno Gandia returned to the island and continued as an activist.

column2: including a well-known intellectual and legislator called José de Diego
column3: sought independence from the United States via political accommodation.  On June 5
column5: President William McKinley named De Diego
column6: together with Rosendo Matienzo Cintrón
column7: José Celso Barbosa
column8: Manuel Camuñas
column9: and Andrés Crosas to an Executive Cabinet under U.S.-appointed Governor Charles H. Allen. The Executive Cabinet also included six American members.De Diego resigned from the position in order to pursue independence. In 1904
column10: he co-founded the Unionist Party along with Luis Muñoz Rivera
column11: Rosendo Matienzo Cintrón and Antonio R. Barceló. De Diego was elected to the House of Delegates
column12: the only locally elected body of government then allowed by the U.S.
column13: over which De Diego presided from 1904 to 1917. The House of Delegates was subject to the U.S. President's veto power and unsuccessfully voted for the island's right to independence and self-government. It petitioned against imposition of U.S. citizenship to Puerto Ricans in 1917
column14: but the US granted citizenship to island residents. Despite these failures
column15: De Diego became known as the "Father of the Puerto Rican Independence Movement."

column1: The newly created Puerto Rico Union Party advocated allowing voters to choose among non-colonial options
column2: including annexation
column3: an independent protectorate
column4: and full autonomy. Another new party called the Puerto Rico Independence Party emerged
column5: founded by Rosendo Matienzo Cintrón in 1912
column6: which promoted Puerto Rico's independence. That same year
column7: Scott Colón
column8: Zeno Gandía
column10: and Luis Lloréns Torres wrote a manifesto for independence. The Independence Party was the first party in the history of the island to openly support independence from the United States as part of its platform.Through the 1930s
column11: U.S. banking interests and corporations expanded their control of lands throughout Latin America.

column1: The main political parties in Puerto Rico have supported a continuing relationship with the United States and been supported by the electorate. By the 1940s voters had elected a majority of Partido Popular Democrático (PPD) members in the legislature. In 1952 they voted by nearly 82% in support of the new constitution of the Estado Libre Associado or Commonwealth. Sixty years later
column2: a majority of those who voted on the second question of a 2012 referendum
column3: to indicate what type of arrangement they preferred
column4: voted to seek admission as a state into the United States. 61.16% voted for statehood
column5: 33.34% voted for free association and 5.49% voted for independence. Hundreds of thousands of voters abstained from the question
column6: so the proportion of voters for statehood was actually 45% of the total eligible electorate rather than a majority.In 1919
column7: Puerto Rico had two major organizations that supported independence: the Nationalist Youth and the Independence Association. Also in 1919
column8: José Coll y Cuchí
column9: a member of the Union Party of Puerto Rico
column10: left the party and formed the Nationalist Association of Puerto Rico. In 1922
column11: these three political organizations joined forces and formed the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party
column12: with Coll y Cuchi as party president. The party's chief goal was to achieve independence from the United States. In 1924 Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos joined the party and was named vice-president.

column3: Dr. Pedro Albizu Campos was elected president of the Nationalist Party.  Under his leadership
column4: in the 1930s the party became the largest independence movement in Puerto Rico. But
column5: after disappointing electoral outcomes and strong repression by the territorial police
column6: by the mid-1930s Albizu opted against the electoral political process. He advocated violent revolution as the means to achieve independence.

column2: the pro-independence Liberal Party of Puerto Rico was founded by Antonio R. Barceló. The Liberal Party's political agenda was the same as that of the original Union Party
column3: urging independence for Puerto Rico. Among those who joined him in the "new" party were Felisa Rincón de Gautier and Ernesto Ramos Antonini.

column2: Luis Muñoz Marín

column4: Río Piedras campus

column6: and summarily executed without a trial at the police headquarters in San Juan.

column3: a march in Ponce by the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party

column1: Acknowledging the importance of the question of Puerto Rican status
column2: Truman supported a plebiscite in Puerto Rico in 1952 on the new constitution
column3: to determine the status of the island's relationship to the U.S. The people voted by nearly 82% in favor of the new constitution and Free Associated State
column4: or Commonwealth. Nationalists criticized the constitution because the Commonwealth was subject to US laws and to approval by the US executive and legislative branches of government
column5: branches which Puerto Ricans did not participate in electing.  As the government suppressed the Nationalist leaders
column6: their political activities and influence waned.In the 1954 United States Capitol shooting incident
column7: four nationalists opened fire on US Representatives during a debate on the floor of the US Congress
column8: wounding five men
column9: one seriously. The Nationalists were tried and convicted in federal court and sentenced effectively to life imprisonment. In 1978 and 1979
column10: their sentences were commuted by President Jimmy Carter to time served
column11: and they were allowed to return to Puerto Rico.

column4: Comandos Armados de Liberación (CAL)

column7: education

column10: and economic development on the Island." The Republican Party asserts that it "support[s] the right of the United States Citizens of Puerto Rico to be admitted to the Union as a fully sovereign state if they freely so determine

column13: while Puerto Rico's status should be supported by a referenda sponsored by "the U.S. government." Neither of the two major parties in Puerto Rico supports independence: the Popular Democratic Party supports the current status of Puerto Rico as a self-governing unincorporated territory
column14: and the New Progressive Party of Puerto Rico supports statehood.

column3: infiltrate
column4: discredit
column5: and disrupt domestic political organizations which it classified as suspect or subversive. The police documented thousands of extensive carpetas (files) concerning individuals of all social groups and ages. Approximately 75

column1: The previous plebiscites provided voters with three options: statehood
column2: free association
column3: and independence. The 2017 referendum offered three options: Statehood
column4: Commonwealth and Independence/Free Association. If the majority vote for the latter
column5: a second vote will be held to determine the preference: full independence as a nation or associated free state status with independence but with a "free and voluntary political association" between Puerto Rico and the United States.The White House Task Force on Puerto Rico offers the following specifics:

column1: Free Association is a type of independence. A compact of Free Association would establish a mutual agreement that would recognize that the United States and Puerto Rico are closely linked in specific ways as detailed in the compact. Compacts of this sort are based on the national sovereignty of each country, and either nation can unilaterally terminate the association. The content of the Compact of Free Association might cover topics such as the role of the US military in Puerto Rico
column2: the use of the U.S. currency
column3: free trade between the two entities
column4: and whether Puerto Ricans would be U.S. citizens.Former Governor Ricardo Rosselló was strongly in favor of statehood to help develop the economy and help to "solve our 500-year-old colonial dilemma ... Colonialism is not an option . ... It's a civil rights issue ... 3.5 million citizens seeking an absolute democracy
column5:
he told the news media. Benefits of statehood include an additional $10 billion per year in federal funds, the right to vote in presidential elections, higher Social Security and Medicare benefits, and a right for its government agencies and municipalities to file for bankruptcy. The latter is currently prohibited.At approximately the same time as the referendum, Puerto Rico's legislators voted on a bill that allows the Governor to draft a state constitution and hold elections to choose senators and representatives to the federal Congress. Regardless of the outcome of the 2017 referendum and the bill, action by the United States Congress will be necessary to implement changes to the status of Puerto Rico under the Territorial Clause of the United States Constitution.
